q: their search results. I'm just curious whether it's possible, even if you have consumers' best interests at heart, that you might actually be doing harm to the broader field of tech innovation? If Google Inc. as a search engine loses sight of what users really want, I'm sure there will be enough companies out there willing to fulfill that need. That's why competition is such a good thing. It keeps everyone honest, and clearly it keeps every company involved focused on the users. I believe a competitive landscape, an open market, allows Google Inc. and other companies to do the right things for their users, because it's in their best interests when users are happy with the product. Simon Cowell let me sing "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star' to him. He's so nice and I love him." Bethany passed away at a hospice the three days later. Simon Cowell 's spokesman Max Clifford said, He is really upset, he said what a beautiful little girl she was. He is just so sad, and sad for the whole family. She was a very special little girl and Simon Cowell was so touched when she sang for him... his heart goes out to Bethany's mum and dad and he is thinking of them. and provocative.( David Paul Morris/Getty Images) LOS ANGELES-After three weeks in office and days filled with meetings, legislators came up with a proposal that state Treasurer Bill Lockyer calls "realistic and provocative." The plan acknowledges that a balanced remedy of spending reductions and revenues is the best cure, Bill Lockyer said in a statement. The California legislature's logjams during attempts to develop effective responses to the growing deficit had become a perennial problem since the worldwide economic meltdown began. There were too many times, Oprah Winfrey , where I was sitting there bored, and I thought, "The end of the day, the audience doesn't tune in to watch me being bored. a reality distortion field that may have made enemies but also bestowed an ineffable cool on his entire company. Larry, by all accounts, makes Eric Schmidt look like Steve Jobs . Ken Auletta explains: He is a very private man, who often in meetings looks down at his hand-held Android device, who is not a comfortable public speaker, who hates to have a regimented schedule, who thinks it is an inefficient use of his time to invest too much of it in meetings with journalists or analysts or governments. As C.E.O., the private man will have to become more public. Google's engineer-driven approach to new products has been a long-standing problem.( Google Wave, anybody?) Unlike Apple, it seems to build for engineers and developers, not consumers. That's great when

that new blood, a new perspective, is needed," he said. Whatever happens, IDC's Hilwa said he hopes Eric Schmidt will continue to participate in major decisions at the company. Eric Schmidt , Larry and Sergey Brin have always effectively acted as a co-CEOs, he said. "Being able to put their heads together on important decisions has served them well in the past.
